text.p: These are some of the leading stories in Israeli newspapers on Tuesday.
Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- JERUSALEM POST
- Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu hopes summit will yield deal on Hebron withdrawal.
- Government to hit women, employers for another 350 million shekels in revenues.
- Palestinian Authority stamps fail to get seal of approval on Christmas cards.
- Gasoline and tobacco prices rise.
GLOBES
- Bank of Israel Governor Jacob Frenkel lowers key lending rate by 0.5 percentage point.
- Petrol prices to rise by six to 10 percent, cigarettes by 10.8 to 13.2 percent.
- District court allows granting Kavei Zahav group license to operate international telephone services.
HAARETZ
- United States to give Israel, Palestinian Authority letter of guarantees on the continuation of the peace process.
- Nine Israeli cabinet ministers support the agreement on Hebron withdrawal, four are opposed, five undecided.
- Netanyahu orders his labour minister not to approve for the time being construction of new Jewish homes in Arab East Jerusalem neighbourhood.
- Treasury announces additional taxation, in order to close gap caused by changes in proposed 1997 budget.
- President Ezer Weizman to homosexuals: The respect and rights of all citizens of Israel must be preserved.
MAARIV
- Palestinian President Yasser Arafat demands American guarantees on implementation in full of Israeli-PLO peace deal.
- "Small green alien landed in our barn - and died."
- Police think grenade that killed Israeli on Sunday was thrown by mistake.
YEDIOTH AHRONOTH
- Towards agreement on Hebron.
- First photographs of Yigal Amir, assassin of late prime minister Yitzhak Rabin, in his jail cell.
- Price rises on petrol, cigarettes.
